questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing pain and swelling in her right foot for the past 2 weeks. Initially, the pain was intermittent but it is now constant and she describes it as 8 out of 10 in intensity. She has not had any trauma to the foot or any previous problems with her joints. The pain has not allowed her to continue training for an upcoming marathon. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. She is a model and has to regularly wear stilettos for fashion shows. She appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows swelling of the right forefoot. There is tenderness to palpation over the fifth metatarsal shaft. Pushing the fifth toe inwards produces pain. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although turf toe would result in discrete joint pain in the foot, it affects the first metatarsophalangeal joint, not the fifth metatarsal head. It is also most commonly seen in football or soccer players that play on artificial turf, not marathon runners.

B) INCORRECT:

Morton's neuroma causes swelling and neuropathic pain in the ball of the foot that radiates into the toes. This pain is normally aggravated by activity and by wearing high-heeled shoes, which puts pressure on the area of the neuroma. Although this patient frequently wears stilettos, her pain is somatic rather than neuropathic, and it also occurs with normal shoes. Also, the location of the pain is in her fifth metatarsal, whereas Morton's neuroma usually occurs in the third and fourth intermetatarsal spaces.

C) INCORRECT:

Although acute osteomyelitis can cause an inflamed and swollen foot with tenderness to palpation of the affected joint, this patient lacks other signs and symptoms of infection such as fever or lethargy. She also does not have any risk factors for osteomyelitis, such as an open wound, draining sinus tracts, altered immunity, or diabetes mellitus.

D) CORRECT:

Stress fractures frequently affect people who participate in repetitive high-intensity physical activities such as running or jumping. Bone normally undergoes a remodeling process in physically active people. Increased stress to the bone accelerates this remodeling process, weakening the outer bony surface. This patient has multiple risk factors for stress fractures, including female sex and marathon training. Caloric restriction is another potential risk factor; given this patient's modeling history, the physician should also inquire about daily eating habits. The location of this patient's stress fracture in the fifth metatarsal is common in runners as it has less soft tissue coverage and intrinsic muscle attachments than the lesser metatarsals. It is also the most mobile of all the metatarsals.
Image Description:

Stress fractures of the metatarsals occur following repetitive load bearing on the feet, e.g., during long marches (therefore, they are sometimes called “March fractures”). The second metatarsal shaft is most commonly affected. Stress fractures at the base of the 5th metatarsal shaft have a high risk of nonunion.

E) INCORRECT:

Plantar fasciitis typically presents with pain in the heel and the bottom of the foot, whereas this patient has pain specifically over the fifth metatarsal. Also, plantar fasciitis is due to a noninflammatory structural breakdown of the plantar fascia rather than an inflammatory process; therefore, swelling is rare.
Image Description:

In patients with plantar fasciitis, tenderness can be elicited by applying pressure over the calcaneal insertion of the plantar aponeurosis (dotted circle).

F) INCORRECT:

Freiberg disease commonly affects athletes and young women in the second decade of life. Although Freiberg disease may manifest with pain, swelling, and tenderness to palpation in the metatarsals, it most commonly affects the second or third metatarsal. First or fifth metatarsal involvement is extremely rare.
Image Description:

X-ray right foot (dorsoplantar view)

Sclerosis (green overlay) and flattening (indicated by white line) of the articular surface of the 3rd metatarsal head are consistent with prior avascular necrosis. Osteophytes (examples indicated by red overlay) have formed on both sides of the widened joint space.

Freiberg disease (previously known as Freiberg infarction) is avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis) of a metatarsal bone. It typically develops in the second metatarsal head, but may involve any metatarsal bone.
questions.hint: Other bones that are likely to have a similar pathology include the tibial shaft and femoral neck.

questions.text: A previously healthy 18-year-old army recruit is brought to a military treatment facility because of a 3-week history of right foot pain. He recently started basic infantry training and has been running several kilometers daily. Initially, the pain only occurred while running, but now it is also present at rest. The pain is located diffusely over the right forefoot. Vital signs are within normal range. Examination shows mild swelling over the distal right forefoot. Pressing the metatarsal of the third right toe results in pain. He walks with an antalgic gait. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the right foot shows a slight loss of cortical density and callus formation at the third metatarsal shaft. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Rest and acetaminophen are the treatment of choice of a metatarsal stress fracture. Stress fractures, the incidence of which is highest among athletes and military recruits, typically occur when there is a sudden increase in frequency, duration, or intensity of exercise. With physical activity, the bone normally undergoes a remodeling process to counteract the mechanical stress placed on the bone. However, without adequate rest, the remodeling process is disrupted, which can lead to microfractures of the bone that may eventually coalesce to form a stress fracture. Stress fractures are usually a clinical diagnosis, but imaging can be performed when a definitive diagnosis is required. Conventional x-ray, although specific, is not very sensitive, and findings often appear normal during the first 2–3 weeks. MRI, which is both highly sensitive and specific, is the best imaging modality to confirm the diagnosis.

NSAIDs and COX-2 inhibitors are typically avoided in the treatment of stress fractures due to the risk of nonunion.
Image Description:

Stress fractures of the metatarsals occur following repetitive load bearing on the feet, e.g., during long marches (therefore, they are sometimes called “March fractures”). The second metatarsal shaft is most commonly affected. Stress fractures at the base of the 5th metatarsal shaft have a high risk of nonunion.

B) INCORRECT:

Bone biopsy is usually reserved for patients with suspected bone malignancies and, accordingly, inappropriate in the management of stress fractures. Point tenderness to the bone, swelling, and an antalgic gait might raise concerns for an occult bone malignancy. However, affected patients will typically also present with warning signs (such as fatigue, weight loss, or neurovascular disturbances) and/or lytic bone lesions on radiographic imaging, none of which are present in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Ultrasonography may be used in the initial evaluation of patients with stress fractures, typically showing focal hyperechoic periosteal elevation, hypervascularity, and/or cortical defects. However, ultrasonography would not be appropriate following radiographic imaging since it is unlikely to provide more conclusive findings.

D) INCORRECT:

Technetium bone scan (bone scintigraphy) is a complementary nuclear study used in the evaluation of numerous skeletal pathologies (e.g., malignancies, rheumatologic disorders, infections, etc.). Previously, this imaging modality was used in the diagnosis of occult bone fractures because it is highly sensitive and capable of detecting evidence of stress fractures 2–3 days after injury. However, this is rarely done today because the modality is not very specific.

E) INCORRECT:

Cast immobilization is generally not required in the management of metatarsal stress fractures. In some cases, immobilization or casting is used to augment the treatment of fifth metatarsal fractures.

F) INCORRECT:

CT scan is typically performed if greater anatomical detail of the bone is needed to determine the precise location and/or extent of a suspected stress fracture. However, it is not routinely performed to evaluate or confirm the diagnosis of a stress fracture.

G) INCORRECT:

Internal fixation is generally performed in open, unstable, or severely displaced fractures. Initial therapy of stress fractures is typically conservative, and surgical management is reserved for refractory cases. The exception is fifth metatarsal stress fractures, which are often managed surgically, either immediately or with delayed union. This patient, who has a third metatarsal stress fracture, does not require surgical fixation at this time.
questions.hint: The sudden onset of bony tenderness, soft tissue swelling, antalgic gait, and forefoot pain with weight-bearing following a period of high-intensity exercise is consistent with a metatarsal stress fracture. Cortical density loss and callus formation on x-ray further support this diagnosis.

questions.text: An 18-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-week history of pain in his right foot that increases with physical activity and improves with rest. He is a military recruit who started his basic combat training 6 weeks ago. Before he started military training, he did not exercise regularly. The patient's older brother is a sergeant in the army and the patient has been using his brother's old boots. He has no history of major medical illness and takes no medications. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 60 kg (132 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m2. Physical examination shows mild swelling, erythema, and tenderness to palpation over the right forefoot. An x-ray of the right foot is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Morton neuroma, which typically occurs in the intermetatarsal spaces between the second, third, and fourth metatarsal heads, can cause swelling in the foot and neuropathic pain that is aggravated by physical activity and relieved with rest, as seen here. However, erythema is not expected. Moreover, x-ray findings in Morton neuroma are typically normal or show splaying of the metatarsals due to a widening of the intermetatarsal space; this patient's x-ray findings indicate a different diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

A bunion, or hallux valgus, can be caused by ill-fitting footwear and manifest with foot pain and erythema, which is seen here. However, an x-ray of the foot in hallux vagus typically shows a lateral deviation of the great toe at the metatarsophalangeal joint, which is not seen here.
Image Description:

X-ray of the feet (AP view)

Both the right and left hallux are curved outward, increasing angle 1 and decreasing angle 2 (overlay).

C) INCORRECT:

Hammer toe is a common deformity that can occur due to ill-fitting footwear and manifest with foot pain with exercise, which is seen here. However, hammer toe manifests as hyperextension of the metatarsophalangeal joint and flexion of the proximal interphalangeal joint, and it is usually not associated with swelling or erythema. In addition, the x-ray findings show no obvious deformity of these joints of the lesser toes.
Image Description:

Common deformities of the lesser toes

Hammer toe: PIP flexion; DIP and MTP extension
Claw toe: PIP and DIP flexion; MTP extension
Mallet toe: DIP flexion; PIP and MTP extension

D) INCORRECT:

A ligament sprain in the forefoot can manifest with swelling, erythema, and pain that increases with physical activity and improves with rest, all of which are seen here. However, an isolated ligament sprain does not show pathological findings on x-ray, as seen in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's x-ray shows a fracture of the neck of the second metatarsal and callus formation. The metatarsal bones are common sites for stress fractures, which are typically caused by repetitive, high-intensity activity and/or by a sudden increase in the intensity of physical activity, as seen with this army recruit. Such stress to the bone can increase the level of bone resorption to a degree that overwhelms the bone's ability to adapt to the stress, resulting in multiple microfractures that coalesce over time to form a larger break in the bone cortex. Risk factors for stress fractures include ill-fitting footwear (this patient is using his brother's old boots that may not fit him properly), decreased bone density (e.g., osteoporosis), and severe caloric restriction (e.g., in anorexia nervosa). Other important sites for stress fractures are the tibia (most common site), calcaneus, and navicular bone.

F) INCORRECT:

Metatarsalgia, which is pain along the plantar surface of the metatarsal heads, can worsen with physical activity, which is seen here. However, metatarsalgia is diagnosed clinically and would not show pathological findings on x-ray, as seen in this patient.
questions.hint: Although this patient's x-ray shows a pathological finding, patients with this condition often have normal x-ray findings for the first 2–3 weeks after the onset of symptoms.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of pain in his right heel for the past month. Initially, the pain was only present when he took his first steps in the morning or after running for a while, but now it is constant. He is unable to put any weight on his right foot. He recently traveled and spent a lot of time walking to various tourist attractions over the course of 6 weeks. He has no other history of serious illness and takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows mild swelling of the right heel. There is tenderness to palpation on the medial and lateral aspects of the posterior right heel; compressing the sides of the heel between the fingers elicits pain. The plantar surface of the heel is only mildly tender to palpation. Sensation is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Achilles tendinopathy manifests with heel pain during activity and can be caused by an increase in physical exercise (e.g., extensive walking over a long period of time, like this patient's six-week trip). However, pain in Achilles tendinopathy is typically localized 2–6 cm (0.8–2.4 in) above the insertion of the Achilles tendon at the posterior calcaneus. Furthermore, tenderness and pain upon squeezing the medial and lateral sides of the posterior calcaneus are not expected findings in Achilles tendinopathy and suggest a different condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Plantar fasciitis is caused by sudden changes in training intensity and excessive exercise (e.g., extensive walking over a long period of time, like this patient's six-week trip) and manifests with heel pain that worsens after long periods of inactivity. However, tenderness and pain upon squeezing the medial and lateral sides of the posterior calcaneus are not expected findings in plantar fasciitis and suggest a different condition.

C) CORRECT:

Calcaneal stress fractures are typically caused by repetitive, high-intensity activity (e.g., extensive walking over a long period of time, like this patient's six-week trip). These fractures commonly manifest with heel swelling and heel pain upon activity. While these symptoms may also be seen in other conditions (e.g., plantar fasciitis, heel pad syndrome, Achilles tendinopathy), tenderness to palpation and positive calcaneal squeeze test (pain upon compression of the posterior sides of the heel) are specific for calcaneal stress fractures. Diagnosis can be confirmed with MRI. Note that conventional x-rays might not show any signs of fracture immediately; a subtle sclerotic band may be visible after two to three weeks. Treatment options depend on the patient's symptoms and may include activity restrictions and acetaminophen for pain relief.

D) INCORRECT:

Tarsal tunnel syndrome (TTS) can manifest with heel pain that worsens with walking. However, patients with TTS typically present with paresthesia or numbness in the area innervated by the tibial nerve (heel, sole, and first three toes). Furthermore, tenderness and pain upon squeezing the medial and lateral sides of the posterior calcaneus are not expected findings in TTS and suggest a different condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Heel pad syndrome can be caused by chronic overload (e.g., extensive walking over a long period of time, like this patient's six-week trip) and manifests with heel pain and tenderness, similar to what is seen here. However, tenderness and pain upon squeezing the medial and lateral sides of the posterior calcaneus are not expected findings in heel pad syndrome and suggest a different condition.
questions.hint: This condition is most often seen in military recruits and long-distance runners.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 21 years
Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: emergency department
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “The pain in my leg is unbearable.”
History of Present Illness:


5-week history of pain in right lower extremity
pain worsens with activity and is relieved with rest and ibuprofen
no history of trauma
patient is a professional dancer and practices 6–8 hours most days of the week; she is very worried that she will have to stop dancing

Past Medical History:

one urinary tract infection; treated successfully 2 months ago
no serious illness

Medications:
ibuprofen
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:
noncontributory
Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI



35.8°C(96.4°F)
51/min
14/min
100/62 mm Hg
-
178 cm(5 ft 10 in)
60 kg(132 lb)
19 kg/m2




Appearance: mildly uncomfortable
Skin: xerosis; no rashes
Pulmonary: clear lung fields
Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs
Abdominal: soft and nontender; liver and spleen cannot be palpated
Extremities: tenderness and mild swelling over the medial aspect of the right proximal tibia; hopping on the right leg exacerbates pain; dorsalis pedis pulses intact
Neurologic: muscle strength 5/5 throughout; sensation intact

Diagnostic Studies

x-ray of the right knee: shown


It is most appropriate to obtain specific additional history regarding which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Morning stiffness can occur in osteoarthritis, which manifests with pain that worsens during or after exercise and is relieved with rest. However, x-rays in osteoarthritis typically show irregular joint space narrowing, osteophytes, and/or subchondral sclerosis, but not stress fractures. Additionally, osteoarthritis is most common in individuals aged > 50 years.

B) INCORRECT:

Night sweats and long-lasting bone pain can occur in infectious bone diseases (e.g., chronic osteomyelitis, bone tuberculosis) and in certain bone tumors (e.g., osteosarcoma). However, x-rays in chronic osteomyelitis show bone destruction, sequestrum formation, and/or periosteal reactions. In osteosarcoma, x-rays show lytic bone lesions adjacent to sclerotic lesions (moth-eaten appearance) and/or Codman triangles. Stress fractures are not typically seen in these diseases.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient may have received a fluoroquinolone for her recent urinary tract infection. One side effect of fluoroquinolones is tendinopathy, which causes pain that worsens with physical activity. However, fluoroquinolone tendinopathy most commonly affects the Achilles tendon and does not cause stress fractures of the tibia.

D) CORRECT:

Repetitive microtrauma can cause bone remodeling, leading to stress fractures. Risk factors for stress fractures include female sex, prolonged periods of high-intensity activity (e.g., dancing) without adequate rest, and poor nutrition and/or low calorie intake. Many athletes have borderline low BMI and blood pressure as well as physiological sinus bradycardia. However, these findings in combination with xerosis and low body temperature raise suspicion for caloric restriction, which requires evaluation of dietary history.

Other risk factors for stress fractures include calcium and vitamin D deficiencies, improper technique during physical activity, and ill-fitting footwear.

E) INCORRECT:

Urinary symptoms such as foamy urine (due to proteinuria) can occur in multiple myeloma (MM), features of which include spontaneous fractures and bone pain. However, MM most commonly manifests with back pain, not limb pain, and with signs of anemia and hypercalcemia (e.g., constipation, muscle weakness). Additionally, x-rays in MM show lytic lesions, which appear as punched-out holes.

F) INCORRECT:

Cigarette smoking is a risk factor for osteoporosis, which can lead to stress fractures. However, the onset of osteoporosis typically occurs at 50–70 years of age. This patient's young age and other examination findings (e.g., bradycardia, low BMI) suggest another cause for reduced bone density.
questions.hint: This patient's x-ray of the right knee shows a stress fracture in the medial proximal tibial metaphysis.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old woman reports a one-week history of pain in her right shin. She has been training for her physical fitness assessment as a military recruit and has been increasing her runs by one mile per day. After running for 2 weeks, she noted pain over the distal media tibia. The pain occurs during every run and improves with rest.
The right shin has no deformity, erythema, or warmth. There is mild edema and focal tenderness to palpation over the distal third of the medial tibia.
A radiograph of the tibia is obtained (figure).
What is the most appropriate initial management recommendation for this patient?

choices.text: Alternate daily running with cross-training activities
Refrain from running until pain-free, then initiate a gradual return to a running program
Initiate therapy with a bone stimulator

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cross-training activities and shock-absorbing orthotics have been shown to limit the occurrence of stress fractures, but they should not be used as initial management or in lieu of activity reduction.

B) INCORRECT:

Studies of the injection of platelet-rich plasma are ongoing for a variety of soft-tissue and bone problems, but there is no evidence suggesting a benefit for stress fractures.

C) CORRECT:

Stress fractures are common lower-extremity injuries that typically occur in athletes and military recruits after a sudden increase in activity. The most common site is the tibia, followed by the navicular bone and the metatarsals. The pain of a tibial stress fracture is typically exacerbated by activity and improves with rest. Affected patients typically have point tenderness in the tibia with a normal radiograph in the acute setting but evidence of a healing fracture if repeat radiographs are obtained several weeks later.

The best initial treatment for a tibial stress fracture is immediate reduction of activity to a level of pain-free functioning. Reexamination should occur at 2-week intervals. When symptoms have completely resolved, activity may be increased gradually.

Continuing activity in the presence of pain, even tolerable discomfort, increases the possibility of prolonged recovery and potential need for surgical intervention.

Key learning point: The appropriate initial management approach for a tibial stress fracture is to reduce activity to a level of pain-free functioning.

D) INCORRECT:

Cross-training activities and shock-absorbing orthotics have been shown to limit the occurrence of stress fractures, but they should not be used as initial management or in lieu of activity reduction.

E) INCORRECT:

Bone stimulators have been suggested for tibial stress fractures, but current evidence does not support their use before a period of rest and protected weight-bearing.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old female military cadet reports worsening pain in her left shin. The pain started when she initiated military training, and it now limits her ability to participate in hikes, marching, and training drills. The pain is most notable during and after activity.
Her knee and ankle range of motion are equal and unrestricted bilaterally. She has no atrophy on examination, but the anteromedial aspect of her left lower extremity is very tender over the bone.
Anteroposterior and lateral radiographs of the left tibia are unremarkable for soft-tissue swelling or periosteal change. There are no cortical breaks.
Which one of the following approaches is most appropriate for initial management of this patient?

choices.text: Stretching and use of antiinflammatory drug therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Surgical treatment of tibial stress fractures is typically reserved for those involving the anterior cortex of the tibia and the "dreaded black line" on a radiograph.

B) INCORRECT:

Electrical (or ultrasound) bone stimulation has not shown reproducible benefits for tibial stress fracture and is not routinely recommended.

C) INCORRECT:

Iontophoresis of glucocorticoids into the site has not shown reproducible benefits for tibial stress fracture and is not routinely recommended.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s symptoms and history are suggestive of a tibial stress fracture. Stress fractures should be considered in patients who present with tenderness or edema that started after a recent increase in activity.

Tibial stress fractures are most often reported in long-distance runners and military recruits, and women are more commonly affected than men. Typical symptoms include progressively worsening pain along the tibia that is exacerbated by activity, tenderness along the affected region, and possible swelling. An initial radiograph may be negative. At-risk individuals include those who are deconditioned, those involved in prolonged weight-bearing physical activity, and those with diminished bone mineral density. Medial tibial stress syndrome and gastrocnemius or soleus injuries should also be considered in the differential diagnosis.

The recommended initial management for a tibial stress fracture is rest and immobilization. Physical activity and weight-bearing activities should be limited. More extensive treatment may be required if radiographs show a so-called dreaded black line, consistent with a break in the cortex.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial management approach for an uncomplicated tibial stress fracture is rest and immobilization.

E) INCORRECT:

Stretching is beneficial for calf strains but is not effective for managing stress fractures.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman reports a one-week history of pain in her right shin. She has been training for her physical fitness assessment as a military recruit and has been increasing her runs by one mile per day. After running for 2 weeks, she noted pain over the medial distal tibia. The pain occurs during every run and improves with rest. The right shin has no deformity, erythema, or warmth. There is mild edema and focal tenderness to palpation over the distal third of the medial tibia. X-ray of the right tibia is shown. What is the most appropriate initial management recommendation for this patient?

choices.text: Alternate daily running with cross-training activities
Refrain from running until pain-free, then initiate a gradual return to a running program
Initiate therapy with a bone stimulator

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cross-training activities and shock-absorbing orthotics have been shown to limit the occurrence of stress fractures, but they should not be used as initial management or in lieu of activity reduction.

B) INCORRECT:

Studies of the injection of platelet-rich plasma are ongoing for a variety of soft-tissue and bone problems, but there is no evidence suggesting a benefit for stress fractures.

C) CORRECT:

Stress fractures are common lower-extremity injuries that typically occur in athletes and military recruits after a sudden increase in activity. The most common site is the tibia, followed by the navicular bone and the metatarsals. The pain of a tibial stress fracture is typically exacerbated by activity and improves with rest. Affected patients typically have point tenderness in the tibia with a normal radiograph in the acute setting but evidence of a healing fracture if repeat radiographs are obtained several weeks later.

The best initial treatment for a tibial stress fracture is immediate reduction of activity to a level of pain-free functioning. Reexamination should occur at 2-week intervals. After complete resolution of symptoms, a gradual increase in activity is appropriate.

Continuing activity in the presence of pain, even tolerable discomfort, increases the possibility of prolonged recovery and potential need for surgical intervention.

Key learning point: The appropriate initial management approach for a tibial stress fracture is to reduce activity to a level of pain-free functioning.

D) INCORRECT:

Cross-training activities and shock-absorbing orthotics have been shown to limit the occurrence of stress fractures, but they should not be used as initial management or in lieu of activity reduction.

E) INCORRECT:

Bone stimulators have been suggested for tibial stress fractures, but current evidence does not support their use before a period of rest and protected weight-bearing.
questions.hint: Excessive repetitive force through the tibia (e.g., from running) in a military recruit raises suspicion for a stress fracture.

Initially, the pain was intermittent but it is now constant and she describes it as 8 out of 10 in intensity. She has not had any trauma to the foot or any previous problems with her joints. Examination shows swelling of the right forefoot. There is tenderness to palpation over the fifth metatarsal shaft. Pushing the fifth toe inwards produces pain. A) INCORRECT:

This patient has multiple risk factors for stress fractures, including female sex and marathon training. Caloric restriction is another potential risk factor; given this patient's modeling history, the physician should also inquire about daily eating habits. The location of this patient's stress fracture in the fifth metatarsal is common in runners as it has less soft tissue coverage and intrinsic muscle attachments than the lesser metatarsals. It is also the most mobile of all the metatarsals.
Image Description:

Stress fractures of the metatarsals occur following repetitive load bearing on the feet, e.g., during long marches (therefore, they are sometimes called “March fractures”). The second metatarsal shaft is most commonly affected. Stress fractures at the base of the 5th metatarsal shaft have a high risk of nonunion.

D) INCORRECT:

Plantar fasciitis typically presents with pain in the heel and the bottom of the foot, whereas this patient has pain specifically over the fifth metatarsal. Also, plantar fasciitis is due to a noninflammatory structural breakdown of the plantar fascia rather than an inflammatory process; therefore, swelling is rare.
Image Description:

In patients with plantar fasciitis, tenderness can be elicited by applying pressure over the calcaneal insertion of the plantar aponeurosis (dotted circle).

E) INCORRECT:

Freiberg disease commonly affects athletes and young women in the second decade of life. Although Freiberg disease may manifest with pain, swelling, and tenderness to palpation in the metatarsals, it most commonly affects the second or third metatarsal. First or fifth metatarsal involvement is extremely rare.
Image Description:

X-ray right foot (dorsoplantar view)

Sclerosis (green overlay) and flattening (indicated by white line) of the articular surface of the 3rd metatarsal head are consistent with prior avascular necrosis. Osteophytes (examples indicated by red overlay) have formed on both sides of the widened joint space.

Freiberg disease (previously known as Freiberg infarction) is avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis) of a metatarsal bone. It typically develops in the second metatarsal head, but may involve any metatarsal bone.
questions.hint: Other bones that are likely to have a similar pathology include the tibial shaft and femoral neck.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a one-week history of right shin pain. She has been training for a physical fitness assessment as a military recruit and has increased her running distance by one mile per day. After two weeks of running, she developed pain over the medial distal tibia. The pain occurs during every run and improves with rest. On examination, there is no deformity, erythema, or warmth of the right shin, but there is mild edema and focal tenderness over the distal third of the medial tibia. An X-ray of the right tibia is provided. Which one of the following is the most appropriate initial management recommendation?

choices.text: Alternate daily running with cross-training activities.
Refrain from running until pain-free, then initiate a gradual return to a running program.
Initiate therapy with a bone stimulator.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cross-training activities and shock-absorbing orthotics have been shown to limit the occurrence of stress fractures, but they should not be used as initial management or in lieu of activity reduction.

B) CORRECT:

Stress fractures are common lower-extremity injuries that typically occur in athletes and military recruits after a sudden increase in activity. The most common site is the tibia, followed by the navicular bone and the metatarsals. The pain of a tibial stress fracture is typically exacerbated by activity and improves with rest. Affected patients typically have point tenderness in the tibia with a normal radiograph in the acute setting but evidence of a healing fracture if repeat radiographs are obtained several weeks later.

The best initial treatment for a tibial stress fracture is immediate reduction of activity to a level of pain-free functioning. Reexamination should occur at 2-week intervals. After complete resolution of symptoms, a gradual increase in activity is appropriate.

Continuing activity in the presence of pain, even tolerable discomfort, increases the possibility of prolonged recovery and potential need for surgical intervention.

Key learning point: The appropriate initial management approach for a tibial stress fracture is to reduce activity to a level of pain-free functioning.

C) INCORRECT:

Bone stimulators have been suggested for tibial stress fractures, but current evidence does not support their use before a period of rest and protected weight-bearing.

D) INCORRECT:

Studies of the injection of platelet-rich plasma are ongoing for a variety of soft-tissue and bone problems, but there is no evidence suggesting a benefit for stress fractures.

E) INCORRECT:

Cross-training activities and shock-absorbing orthotics have been shown to limit the occurrence of stress fractures, but they should not be used as initial management or in lieu of activity reduction.
questions.hint: Excessive repetitive force through the tibia (e.g., from running) in a military recruit raises suspicion for a stress fracture.

questions.text: A 19-year-old college basketball player presents with a 2-week history of progressive left foot pain that began during preseason training. The pain is localized to the lateral midfoot, worsens with running, and improves with rest. Physical examination shows tenderness over the lateral aspect of the midfoot with minimal swelling. Plain radiographs show no acute fracture. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Prescribe NSAIDs and recommend rest for 1 week
Immobilize and refer to orthopedic surgery
Apply elastic bandage and allow return to play
Recommend activity modification and repeat radiographs in 10 days
Prescribe acetaminophen and walking boot for 4 weeks

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

NSAIDs may delay healing and increase nonunion risk in stress fractures. Additionally, the lateral midfoot location suggests a possible high-risk stress fracture requiring more aggressive management than simple rest.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Despite normal initial radiographs, the clinical presentation suggests a possible proximal 5th metatarsal stress fracture, which is high-risk and prone to complications like nonunion and fracture progression.

C) INCORRECT:

Allowing immediate return to play without definitive diagnosis is inappropriate when stress fracture is suspected. This approach risks fracture progression and complications, especially in high-risk locations.

D) INCORRECT:

Repeat radiographs in 10 days is appropriate for suspected low-risk stress fractures, but the lateral midfoot location raises concern for high-risk proximal 5th metatarsal involvement, which requires immediate advanced imaging and specialist consultation.

E) INCORRECT:

While acetaminophen is appropriate for pain control and walking boot provides some protection, this approach lacks the definitive diagnosis and specialist evaluation required for suspected high-risk stress fractures in competitive athletes.
